subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I follow up a woman after a miscarriage?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ensure that arrangements for routine antenatal care are cancelled (if they have been started).
  • Discuss any questions she has about her miscarriage, including: 
    • The causes and risk factors of miscarriage. 
    • When to resume sexual intercourse.
      • Advise avoidance of sexual intercourse until miscarriage symptoms have completely settled.
    • Trying for another baby.
      • Explain that menstruation can be expected to resume within 4–8 weeks of the miscarriage, and ovulation will occur before this.
      • For women who wish to become pregnant, advise that they can do so as soon as they feel psychologically and physically ready, and offer pre-conception advice. See the CKS topic on Pre-conception - advice and management for more information.
      • For women who do not wish to become pregnant, advise the use of contraception immediately after the miscarriage.
  • Assess the woman's psychological well-being, and offer counselling if appropriate.
    • Be aware that:
      • Grief, anxiety, and depression are common following miscarriage.
      • Grief following miscarriage is comparable in nature, intensity, and duration to grief reactions in people suffering other types of major loss.
      • Distress is commonly at its worst up to 6 weeks after a miscarriage.
    • The following leaflet produced by the miscarriage association may be helpful:
      • Your feelings after miscarriage (pdf)
  • Ensure that all rhesus-negative women who have had a surgical procedure to manage miscarriage have received anti-D immunoglobulin. 
    • Be aware that anti-D immunoglobulin should not be given to women who:
      • Receive solely medical management for a miscarriage.
      • Have had a threatened miscarriage.
      • Have had a complete miscarriage.
  • Provide additional patient information on miscarriage. For example:
    • The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) has a patient information leaflet (PIL) on Early miscarriage. 
    • The Miscarriage Association has several PILs on miscarriage.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage: Diagnosis and initial management [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012].

Offering a follow-up appointment
  • This recommendation is based on the expert opinion of the NICE Guideline Development Group (GDG) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012] and evidence from a Cochrane systematic review [Murphy, 2012].
    • The NICE GDG reviewed the quantitative and qualitative evidence from eight studies (which varied from very low to high quality) and concluded that most women do not experience significant anxiety and depression following miscarriage and that counselling support therefore had little impact [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012]. The GDG emphasised that formal counselling is very different to emotional and psychological support.
    • The GDG found the qualitative data from these trials (moderate to low quality) to be the most helpful at informing practice. Women described their experience of care and commented on what support they would have liked. Based on this descriptive data, the GDG recommended that all women should be offered a follow-up appointment, and made the following comments (which also reflected their own experience):
      • They believed that offering the appointment would have a beneficial effect even for those women who chose not to accept it. For some women a follow-up appointment is valuable but others do not want or need an appointment.
      • Many women appreciate the opportunity to discuss possible reasons for the miscarriage and discuss planning for the future.
      • Only a minority of women would attend the follow-up appointment.
      • Some women might feel the need for a follow-up appointment at a later date.
    • A Cochrane systematic review (search date December 2011) also concluded that women should be able to choose what support they wanted after a miscarriage [Murphy, 2012].
      • The review investigated whether follow up with counselling affects the psychological well-being of women following miscarriage and included six randomized controlled trials (n=1001 women).
      • All of the trials compared counselling with no counselling.
      • The evidence was insufficient to demonstrate the superiority of either no intervention or counselling.
Cancelling further antenatal appointments
  • CKS recommends cancelling antenatal care arrangements to avoid unnecessary distress for the woman.
Trying for another baby
  • CKS identified a systematic review and meta-analysis (n = 1,043,840) that aimed to determine if a short interpregnancy interval (IPI, less than 6 months) following miscarriage is associated with adverse outcomes in the next pregnancy [Kangatharan, 2017].
    • The results showed that an IPI of less than 6 months is associated with no increase in the risks of adverse outcomes in the pregnancy following miscarriage compared with delaying pregnancy for at least 6 months.
      • With an IPI of less than 6 months, the overall risk of further miscarriage and preterm delivery were significantly reduced.
      • The pooled risks of stillbirth, low birthweight, and pre-eclampsia were not affected by IPI.
      • Similar findings were obtained in subgroup analyses when IPI of less than 6 months was compared with IPI of 6–12 months and more than12 months.
    • The evidence suggests that delaying a pregnancy following a miscarriage is not beneficial and unless there are specific reasons for delay, couples should be advised to try for another pregnancy as soon as they feel ready.
Being aware of possible psychological distress
  • This information is based on evidence on the prevalence and severity of psychological distress following miscarriage [Brier, 1999; Brier, 2004; Brier, 2008].
  • Expert opinion in a review article is that women should be screened frequently for depressive symptoms beginning at 6 weeks following a miscarriage and women experiencing clinically significant symptoms beyond 2 months after miscarriage should undergo formal mental health evaluation and treatment [Nynas, 2015].
Ensuring that anti-D immunoglobulin has been given where appropriate
  • The NICE GDG reviewed the evidence for anti-D rhesus prophylaxis for women with a miscarriage (or threatened miscarriage) in the first trimester [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012].
    • Although the quality of the evidence was very low, the NICE GDG felt that, taken as a whole, there was evidence of a risk of sensitization for women if they did not receive anti-D rhesus prophylaxis following a first trimester miscarriage. 
    • The NICE GDG was informed that the chance of sensitization increases when there is a greater likelihood of mixing between the maternal and fetal blood, such as during surgical management of a miscarriage. For this reason, the GDG recommends that all rhesus-negative women who have had a surgical procedure to manage miscarriage should receive anti-D rhesus prophylaxis.
    • Based on their clinical experience, the NICE GDG considered the risk of significant fetal and maternal blood mixing during a spontaneous miscarriage or following treatment with misoprostol to be low and therefore does not recommend anti-D rhesus prophylaxis in these cases.
